data.title: CIMG Disclosed Failure to Satisfy a Continued Listing Rule or Standard
data.description:
On February 23, 2026, the company received a Nasdaq letter stating the Hearings Panel will consider its non-compliance with Listing Rule 5250(c)(1) due to not timely filing its Form 10-Q for the period ended December 31, 2025, as an additional basis for potential delisting during the monitor period. The notice has no immediate impact on trading, and the company is working to file the report as soon as practicable.

Original SEC Filing: CIMG Inc. [ IMG ] - 8-K - Feb. 27, 2026

Disclaimer
This is an AI-powered summary. It may contain inaccuracies. Consider verifying important information with the source. Please note this summary is solely based on documents filed with the SEC.

  • Record date is end of business Feb 28, 2026; payments expected on or about Mar 20, 2026 in cash or via DRIP.
  • Class C has no distribution presented as it is an accumulating class with income accruing to NAV.

data.title: Advanced Drainage Systems Prices $500 Million 2034 Notes and Expands Credit Facilities
data.description:
Advanced Drainage Systems completed a $500 million offering of 5.375% senior notes due 2034 and amended its senior credit facilities, boosting the revolving capacity to $750 million and adding a new $600 million term loan maturing in 2033. Proceeds from the notes, together with the term loan, will refinance the company's senior secured credit facility and support the redemption of its 2027 notes, strengthening liquidity and extending maturities. The revolver now matures in 2031 with leverage-based pricing and expanded incremental capacity.

Agreement 1: Advanced Drainage Systems Issues $500 Million 5.375% Notes Due 2034 to Refinance Debt

  • Agreement type: 5.375% senior notes due 2034 (Indenture)
  • Counterparty: U.S. Bank Trust Company, as Trustee
  • Signed / Effective: Feb 27 2026 / Feb 27 2026
  • Duration / Termination: Through Mar 01 2034
  • Reason: Refinance credit facility and redeem 2027 notes

Agreement 2: Advanced Drainage Systems Amends Credit Agreement: $750 Million Revolver, $600 Million Term Loan

  • Agreement type: Amended credit agreement with $750m revolver and $600m term loan
  • Counterparty: PNC Bank (revolver agent), Bank of America (term agent), and lenders
  • Signed / Effective: Feb 27 2026 / Feb 27 2026
  • Duration / Termination: Revolver through Feb 27 2031; Term loan through Feb 28 2033
  • Reason: Enhance liquidity and refinance existing debt

Original SEC Filing: ADVANCED DRAINAGE SYSTEMS, INC. [ WMS ] - 8-K - Feb. 27, 2026

Disclaimer

data.title: Deported student refuses flight back to US following threat of second deportation
data.description:
Key points:
  • Any Lucia Lopez Belloza declines flight after threat of second deportation
  • Judge ordered Trump's administration to rectify deportation error
  • Lawyer accuses administration of "gamesmanship" in immigration case

By Nate Raymond

The Trump administration scheduled a Friday flight to bring a deported college student back from Honduras after a judge ordered her return, but she declined to board the plane after U.S. authorities said they may detain and deport her again.

Any Lucia Lopez Belloza, a freshman at Babson College in Massachusetts, had been deported to a country she left when she was 8, after being detained at Boston's Logan International Airport while traveling to spend Thanksgiving with her family in Texas.

The 20-year-old was flown to Honduras on November 22 despite a Massachusetts judge's order the prior day barring her from being deported or transferred out of the state for 72 hours. A government lawyer later apologized for what he called a "mistake."

Boston-based U.S. District Judge Richard Stearns on February 13 ordered President Donald Trump's administration to rectify the error it made during its immigration crackdown by Friday by facilitating her return.

Lopez Belloza told reporters she had been excited to learn on Thursday the administration had arranged for a flight to take her home.

"Hours later, that excitement turned into a nightmare," Lopez Belloza said.

She said a U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement officer misled her by repeatedly telling her on Thursday that if she boarded the plane, she would be released upon landing in the United States.

"I believed him for a second," she said. "I pictured stepping off of the plane and finally being free."

Yet in court filings on Thursday afternoon, the administration said it planned to move to deport her again once she arrived. It said it had the authority to detain her if she took the ICE flight from Honduras to Texas because she was already subject to a final order of removal, which was issued when she was 11.

"I won't mince words," Lopez Belloza said during a virtual press conference. "I am angry. I am sad."

Todd Pomerleau, Lopez Belloza's lawyer, accused the administration of "gamesmanship" and vowed to continue her legal fight.

"I'm not stopping until she's back here, but she's not coming back in handcuffs," he said.

In a court filing later on Friday, the administration said Lopez Belloza failed to appear for a pre-arranged meeting to assist with her departure and did not board the scheduled flight after previously agreeing to come to an airport in San Pedro Sula, Honduras.

A spokesperson for U.S. Attorney Leah Foley, whose office has been fighting Lopez Belloza's legal challenge, in a statement said the ICE-arranged flight was intended to restore the "status quo."

"The status quo that existed prior to her removal was that she was subject to a final order of removal and as the government argued throughout this case, ICE has statutory authority to detain an individual to effectuate such removal," the spokesperson, Christina Sterling, said.

​

data.title: Apple's Latest IPhones And IPads Approved For NATO-Restricted Information
data.description:
CUPERTINO (dpa-AFX) - Apple Inc. [AAPL] announced that its latest iPhone and iPad models running iOS 26 and iPadOS 26 have been approved to handle NATO-restricted information, the lowest tier of NATO-classified data.

This approval, granted by Germany's Federal Office for Information Security (BSI), signifies a notable advancement as historically, classified environments required heavily customized or government-modified devices.

'NATO-restricted' refers to information that would be disadvantageous to NATO's interests if disclosed, but does not rise to higher classification levels such as Confidential or Secret.

The approval means that off-the-shelf Apple devices can be used without the need for special hardened software builds or custom security configurations beyond standard OS protections.

This approval reflects the built-in security features of modern iOS and iPadOS, including end-to-end hardware-backed encryption, Secure Enclave protections, biometric authentication via Face ID, and Memory Integrity Enforcement.

These protections are now considered strong enough to meet formal international government security requirements without the need for custom defense-only modifications.

The decision by the BSI to clear Apple devices for use across NATO nations represents a growing trust in commercial hardware security, reducing the reliance on expensive, purpose-built government devices.

This development also provides a credibility boost for Apple in government procurement, defense contracting, and regulated industries.

The approval does not imply clearance for higher NATO classifications, such as NATO Confidential, Secret, or Top Secret, nor does it mean the devices are invulnerable to compromise.

It simply indicates that their architecture meets the defined security thresholds for the NATO-restricted classification level

data.title: CROWN HOLDINGS, INC. ANNOUNCES 35% DIVIDEND INCREASE
data.description:
(21:05 GMT) *CROWN HOLDINGS, INC. ANNOUNCES 35% DIVIDEND INCREASE >CCK
(21:05 GMT) Press Release: CROWN HOLDINGS, INC. ANNOUNCES 35% DIVIDEND INCREASE

TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 27, 2026 /PRNewswire/ — Crown Holdings, Inc. announced today that its Board of Directors declared a cash dividend of $0.35 per share, payable March 31, 2026, to shareholders of record as of March 17, 2026. This quarterly dividend represents an increase of 35% over the previous dividend of $0.26 per share.

Timothy J. Donahue, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer, stated, "Our 35% dividend increase underscores the strength of our earnings and free cash flow generation, the resilience of our end markets, and our confidence in our operations. Supported by our solid balance sheet, we are well-positioned to consistently return capital to shareholders. We remain committed to our balanced capital allocation framework — maintaining our net leverage ratio at approximately 2.5x, investing prudently to support long-term growth, paying a sustainable and growing dividend, and returning capital through disciplined share repurchases."

Crown Holdings, Inc., through its subsidiaries, is a leading global supplier of rigid packaging products to consumer marketing companies, as well as transit and protective packaging products, equipment and services to a broad range of end markets. World headquarters are located in Tampa, Florida.

For more information, contact:

Kevin C. Clothier, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, (215) 698-5281

Thomas T. Fischer, Vice President, Investor Relations and Corporate Affairs, (215) 552-3720

View original content:https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/crown-holdings-inc-announces-35-dividend-increase-302699868.html

SOURCE Crown Holdings, Inc.

data.title: Blue Moon to Acquire the Apex Germanium and Gallium Mine from Teck to Advance US Critical Mineral Projects to Secure North American Supply
data.description:
TORONTO, Feb. 27, 2026 /CNW/ - Blue Moon Metals Inc. ("Blue Moon" or the "Company") is pleased to announce that Teck American Incorporated, a subsidiary of Teck Resources Limited ("Teck"), has agreed to vend 100% of the past-producing Apex germanium (Ge), gallium (Ga) and copper (Cu) mine located in Utah into Blue Moon (the "Transaction"), becoming a key stakeholder to support an integrated pipeline of US critical mineral projects to secure North American supply. The Transaction adds to an already strong working relationship with key shareholder Hartree Partners LP, an important partner with the US government on their recently announced US$12B critical metals stockpile. Immediate synergies from the Transaction include:

 
a)  The ability to process zinc concentrates from Blue 
     Moon's Blue Moon Mine in California (the "Blue Moon 
     Mine"), where underground development commenced last 
     year, at Teck's Trail Operations, providing the final 
     piece to solidify a fully integrated North American 
     sourced value chain; 
 
b)  A path to redevelop the Apex mine in Utah to potentially 
     unlock an important onshore source of Ge and Ga; 
 
c)  Possible restart of the permitted Springer tungsten 
     mine in Nevada with the potential to supply a sizable 
     portion of US domestic requirements; and 
 
d)  Redevelopment of the larger Springer complex to build 
     critical mineral processing capacity to support the 
     Blue Moon Mine and other mines in the Western US, 
     with logistical connections to Trail as required.

Christian Kargl-Simard, CEO of Blue Moon states, "Underground development at the Blue Moon Mine is advancing well, which together with the acquisition of the Apex Mine and our redevelopment of the Springer metallurgical complex and Springer tungsten mine provides a unique hub and spoke platform for US critical metals growth. Teck and Blue Moon are logical partners, combining Blue Moon's US project pipeline and processing capacity at Teck's Trail Operations. We are excited to leverage our combined infrastructure, industry leading technical knowhow, and financing depth to advance our US domestic copper, zinc, tungsten and now germanium and gallium projects to provide long-term feed for our Springer complex."

Ian Anderson, Teck Executive Vice President & Chief Commercial Officer commented, "Following our cornerstone investments to rebuild zinc, lead, and silver capacity in Idaho's Silver Valley, revitalizing the long-standing connection between US miners and our smelting and refining complex in Trail, this transaction with Blue Moon marks another important step to develop new US sources of critical minerals. As a supportive stakeholder, we look forward to working with Blue Moon as they advance their mines and processing complex in California, Utah, and Nevada, as well as to exploring other ways to strengthen North American supply chains together."

Blue Moon Mine, California (Gold, Zinc, Silver, Copper, Lead, Barite)

Blue Moon's advanced-stage 100%-owned Blue Moon zinc-copper-gold-silver project is located in east-central California in Mariposa County, with direct access to roads and power. Originally mined by Hecla Mining Company from 1943-1945, the mine produced 55,656 tons grading 12.3% zinc, 0.36% copper, 0.48% lead, 3.75 oz/ton silver and 0.062 oz/ton gold. The property was later actively explored and advanced during 1980s and 1990s by Imperial Metals, Boliden and Lac Minerals (now Barrick).

Since the new management team and board started in November 2024, Blue Moon has completed a modern review, verification, and analysis of the historical data, and in March 2025 published a NI 43-101 compliant resource estimate and a preliminary economic assessment to support a mine restart, demonstrating potential for annual average production of 22,566 oz gold, 62.3M lbs of zinc, 681,784 oz silver and 7.2 Mlbs copper over a +10 year mine life (see press release dated March 3, 2025).

The Company received permits in April 2025 and began construction of an exploration decline on October 6, 2025. The decline is progressing well with over 140 meters advanced to date and underground diamond drilling is underway in an effort to upgrade resources to reserves. Production is forecasted to begin in 2028 and technical work is ongoing to support processing the material at Blue Moon's Springer complex in Nevada to produce copper and zinc concentrates with appreciable gold and silver by-product credits, as well as potentially a lead concentrate and clean pyrite and barite products.

By combining the Blue Moon Mine in California, with processing at the Springer Complex in Nevada and smelting of the zinc concentrate at Teck's Trail Operations in Canada, Blue Moon and Teck are building a fully integrated North American value chain.

Apex Mine, Utah (Germanium, Gallium, Copper)

Apex is a historic underground mine in southwest Utah, which was previously mined for copper oxide, and later for Ge and Ga. This underground mine became the primary producer of gallium and germanium in the United States when Musto Explorations Ltd. brought it into production in the mid 1980's and again with Hecla Mining Company in the 1990's. During its peak year of operations, Apex produced 10,270 tons yielding 1,645 lb Ga, 5,634 lbs of Ge, and 224,800 lbs of Cu.

Hecla completed a feasibility study in 1989, reporting a reserve of 230,200 tons of 0.100% Ge, 0.046% Ga and 1.6% Cu. A historical reserve estimate(1) by Ken Krahulec in 2018 estimated 1 MT @ 0.087% Ge, 0.033% Ga, 1.8% Cu and 41 g/t Ag. The Ge and Ga are 10-100x higher grade than most Ge and Ga deposits, with in-situ value per ton similar to 0.5 oz/T gold ores. Beyond the historical reserves, Hecla also identified several additional breccia bodies as prospective exploration targets, including the Paymaster, Cavern, and 500 North pipes, along with further oxide zones in the immediate mine area.

(1) As at the date of this news release, a qualified person has not completed sufficient work to classify the historical estimates above as current mineral resources or mineral reserves in accordance with NI 43-101 and Blue Moon is not treating the historical estimate as current mineral resources or mineral reserves. In order to verify the historical estimates, the Company needs to engage a qualified person to review the historical data, review any work completed on the property since and complete a new technical report. Blue Moon views this historical data as an indicator of the potential size and grade of the mineralized deposits, and this data is relevant to Company's future plans with respect to the property.

Subject to renewed permits and with the intent to reopen the mine, the Company plans to fast track efforts to advance the technical studies, metallurgical testing, process flowsheets, permitting and community engagement to support a final investment decision. In parallel, Blue Moon is evaluating options for a new processing line at the Company's Springer complex to process the Apex material and provide an integrated United States Ge and Ga value chain.

Springer Complex, Nevada (Multi-commodity Processing Hub)

The Springer property is located on the east flank of the Eugene Mountains, approximately 25 miles southwest of the city of Winnemucca, and 125 miles northeast of the city of Reno, in Pershing County, Nevada. The mine site is approximately 8 miles from Interstate 80, serviced by paved/gravel road, over owned land. The Springer tungsten milling facility is located entirely on private fee lands.

Springer is a former tungsten production facility consisting of a 1,360-ft vertical shaft and underground workings, a 1,200 ton per day mill with automated rod/ball mill grinding and flotation circuits, plus all water rights, and most permits necessary for operation of the facility.

The Springer tungsten property was the site of continuous underground tungsten mining between 1918 and 1958, much of that time controlled first by the Segerstrom family, and later by the Nevada-Massachusetts Mining Company ("NMC"). The General Electric Company ("GE") acquired the property in the 1970's, interested in securing long term tungsten supply assets to support its lighting and industrial tools businesses. The current mine and mill were constructed by Utah International Inc. ("UII", later became BHP Minerals Group) for GE in the mid 1970's, and was subsequently commissioned and operated by GE for 8 months in 1982. The property has not been actively mined since October 1982, and the underground workings are currently flooded to a depth of approximately 375 feet. EMC Metals Corp. acquired the Springer mine and associated properties from GE in 2006. Between that purchase date and today, considerable refurbishment and renewal has been undertaken to the mill, control systems, hoist house, and an up-rating of the mill throughput from a nominal 950 tpd to a current 1,350 tpd capacity, and an estimated 1,200 tpd throughput after availabilities (89%).

Centrally located with access to diverse mineral sources and existing road and rail infrastructure, the Springer Mine and Mill is well situated to become a regional metallurgical complex. With established tailings and water management systems, the brownfield site provides significant opportunities to reduce capital and permitting timelines compared to a greenfield development.

data.title: Block Inc. Cuts Over 4,000 Jobs, Cites AI Efficiencies
data.description:
WASHINGTON (dpa-AFX) - Block Inc. (formerly Square), the parent company of Cash App and Afterpay, has announced significant layoffs, reducing its workforce by 40% to just under 6,000 employees. The move, led by co-founder and CEO Jack Dorsey, is driven by advancements in artificial intelligence (AI) rather than financial weakness.

According to Dorsey, a 'significantly smaller team, using the tools we're building, can do more and do it better.' CFO Amrita Ahuja echoed this sentiment, stating that the company can 'move faster with smaller, highly talented teams using AI to automate more work.'

The job cuts come after Block's headcount grew sharply during the pandemic, from around 3,800 employees in 2019 to over 10,000 before the layoffs.

Dorsey argues that many tech firms, including Block, overexpanded during the COVID-era demand surge and are now recalibrating their operations, explicitly focusing on AI productivity gains. He predicts that most companies will reach the same conclusion and make similar structural changes within the next year.

Investors responded positively to the announcement, with Block's shares surging as much as 24%. The move fits into a broader tech-sector pattern, as companies like Amazon, Meta Platforms, and Microsoft have all trimmed staff while simultaneously investing heavily in AI infrastructure and tools.

Laid-off Block employees will receive at least 20 weeks of severance (more depending on tenure), equity vesting through the end of May, six months of healthcare, $5,000 in cash, and their corporate devices.

Dorsey views this as a structural shift, rather than just a cost-cutting cycle. He believes that the adoption of AI tools will enable smaller teams, faster execution, and lower overhead, potentially leading to a permanent workforce compression, particularly in white-collar and tech roles.

Copyright(c) 2026 RTTNews.com. All Rights Reserved

Copyright RTT News/dpa-AFX

data.title: ALLIANCEBERNSTEIN GLOBAL HIGH INCOME FUND, INC. REPORTS THIRD QUARTER EARNINGS
data.description:
NEW YORK, Feb. 27, 2026 /PRNewswire/ — AllianceBernstein Global High Income Fund, Inc. , a registered closed--end investment company, today announced earnings for the third quarter ended December 31, 2025.

Total net assets of the Fund on December 31, 2025 were $985,227,126 as compared with $993,104,684 on September 30, 2025 and $978,431,163 on December 31, 2024. On December 31, 2025, the net asset value per share was $11.43 based on 86,229,677 shares of common stock outstanding.

For the period October 1, 2025 through December 31, 2025, total net investment income was $15,059,136 or $0.17 per share. The total net realized and unrealized loss was $(1,784,553) or $(0.02) per share for the same period.

data.title: CYNGN Inc expected to post a loss of 100 cents a share - Earnings Preview
data.description:
• CYNGN Inc is expected to show a fall in quarterly revenue when it reports results on March 3 (estimated) for the period ending December 31 2025

  • The Mountain View California-based company is expected to report a 2.0% decrease in revenue to $300 thousand from $306 thousand a year ago, according to the estimate from one analyst, based on LSEG data.

  • ​LSEG's mean analyst estimate for CYNGN Inc is for a loss of 100 cents per share.

  • The one available analyst rating on the shares is "buy".

  • The mean earnings estimate of analysts was unchanged in the last three months. ​

  • Wall Street's median 12-month price target for CYNGN Inc is $12.00, about 664.3% above its last closing price of $1.57

data.title: CME cattle futures dive on poor packer margins, lower cash prices
data.description:
By Karl Plume

Chicago Mercantile Exchange cattle futures tumbled for a second straight session on Friday as deeply negative beef packer margins and lower cash cattle prices weighed on the market, analysts said.

A looming strike at a large beef plant in Greeley, Colorado, hung over the market, as a loss of production would dent demand for fed cattle. Elevated beef prices also could come under seasonal pressure, as milder weather that normally ushers in outdoor grilling season remains weeks or months away, analysts said.

"The packer has been losing a significant amount of money for quite a while," said Don Roose, president of U.S. Commodities. "And we know that it's the worst demand time of the year until we hit the grilling season."

The average beef packer margin was estimated at a negative $262.50 per head on Friday, compared with a negative $356.30 per head a week ago, according to livestock marketing advisory service HedgersEdge.

Cash cattle traded this week at prices $2 to $3 per hundredweight lower than last week as packers sought to minimize losses, analysts said.

CME April live cattle futures (LCJ26) closed 4.675 cents lower on Friday at 232.225 cents per pound, a six-week low. April feeder cattle (FCJ26) fell 7.550 cents to finish at 351.200 cents per pound, the lowest price since January 2.

Lean hog futures were steady to weaker on profit-taking following the market's recent rally on strong pork exports and solid domestic demand.

CME April hogs (LHJ26) closed steady at 95.725 cents per pound after hitting their highest level since February 10 at midweek.

data.title: HANMI FINANCIAL CORP SEC 10-K Report
data.description:
Hanmi Financial Corp, a prominent financial institution serving multi-ethnic communities with a focus on the Korean-American community, has released its 2025 Form 10-K report. The report highlights significant financial growth, strategic initiatives aimed at expanding its loan portfolio, and the challenges and risks the company faces in the competitive banking industry.

Financial Highlights

Net Income: Hanmi Financial Corp reported a net income of $76.1 million for 2025, reflecting a 22.3% increase from the previous year. This growth was driven by a $33.4 million increase in net interest income and a $2.4 million increase in noninterest income.

Earnings Per Diluted Share: The company's earnings per diluted share rose to $2.51, compared to $2.05 in the previous year, indicating improved profitability.

Net Interest Income: Net interest income for the year was $236.2 million, a 16.5% increase from the previous year, driven by lower rates paid on deposits and a higher average balance of loans.

Credit Loss Expense: The company recorded a credit loss expense of $14.4 million, up from $4.4 million in the previous year, primarily due to an $8.6 million charge-off during 2025.

Noninterest Income: Noninterest income increased by 7.6% to $34.0 million, mainly due to higher gains on the sale of SBA loans and increased bank-owned life insurance income.

Business Highlights

Revenue Segments: Hanmi Bank's revenues are primarily derived from interest and fees on loans, interest and dividends on securities, service charges, fees on deposit accounts, and sales of SBA and mortgage loans. The bank's client base reflects the multi-ethnic composition of the communities it serves, focusing on the Korean-American community and other multi-ethnic communities across several states.

Geographical Performance: The bank operates in California, Colorado, Georgia, Illinois, New Jersey, New York, Texas, Virginia, and Washington, with a significant focus on markets where businesses are owned by immigrants and minority groups. California remains the largest market, particularly for residential property loans.

Sales Units: The bank's loan portfolio includes real estate loans, commercial and industrial loans, equipment financing agreements, and SBA loans. As of December 31, 2025, the total loan balance was $6.56 billion, reflecting a 5.0% increase from the previous year.

Future Outlook: The bank anticipates potential changes in economic conditions, such as a mild recession starting in the first quarter of 2026, which could impact credit losses. Management is focused on maintaining adequate allowance for credit losses and adjusting strategies based on economic forecasts.

Strategic Initiatives

Strategic Loan Portfolio Growth: The company focused on strategic loan portfolio growth, increasing total loans by $312.0 million, or 5.0%, to $6.56 billion as of December 31, 2025. This growth was driven by strategic initiatives to expand the commercial and industrial and residential real estate portfolios while reducing commercial real estate exposure.

Capital Management: The company repurchased 393,298 shares of its common stock at an average price of $23.91, totaling $9.4 million, under its share repurchase program. The Board of Directors authorized an expansion of the share repurchase program, adding 1.5 million shares to the existing capacity, bringing the total repurchase capacity to approximately 2.3 million shares. The company paid $32.6 million in dividends, or $1.08 per share, in 2025. Stockholders' equity increased by $64.2 million to $796.4 million, driven by net income and a decrease in unrealized after-tax losses on securities.

Future Outlook: The company plans to continue its share repurchase program with an expanded capacity of 2.3 million shares. It aims to maintain a strong capital position, with the Bank's total risk-based capital ratio at 14.25% and the Company's at 15.06%, both exceeding regulatory requirements. The company will focus on managing interest rate risk and liquidity, with increased borrowing capacity through the Federal Reserve Discount Window and other credit lines. The strategic focus will remain on expanding loan portfolios in targeted areas while managing credit risk and maintaining capital adequacy.

Challenges and Risks

Competitive Landscape: Hanmi Financial Corporation faces significant competition in the banking and financial services industry, particularly from larger institutions with greater resources and broader service offerings. The company’s focus on the Korean-American and multi-ethnic communities presents both opportunities and challenges in maintaining its market position.

Lending Risks: Concentrations in certain industries, such as non-residential buildings, hospitality, and retail, pose credit quality risks. Emphasis on commercial lending increases exposure to non-payment and loss risks.

Regulatory Scrutiny: High levels of commercial real estate loans may subject the bank to additional regulatory scrutiny, potentially leading to increased costs or restrictions on lending activities.

Economic Conditions: Adverse economic conditions in key markets like California, Illinois, Texas, Georgia, and New York could impair borrowers’ ability to repay loans and decrease deposit levels.

Inflation and Interest Rates: Rising inflation and interest rates could negatively impact the value of investment securities and increase operational costs.

Environmental Liabilities: Foreclosure on properties could expose the company to environmental liabilities, leading to substantial costs.

Cybersecurity Risks: The company is susceptible to cyber-attacks and data breaches, which could disrupt operations and damage its reputation.

Regulatory Changes: Changes in laws and regulations, including those related to Dodd-Frank, could increase compliance costs and limit business opportunities.

AI and ML Risks: The integration of AI and ML technologies exposes the company to operational, data, regulatory, and reputational risks.

Risk Management: Management highlights the importance of maintaining a strong risk management framework to address the identified risks. The company is focused on enhancing its cybersecurity measures and ensuring compliance with evolving regulatory requirements. Additionally, management is monitoring economic conditions closely to mitigate potential impacts on its loan portfolio and overall financial performance.

SEC Filing: HANMI FINANCIAL CORP [ HAFC ] - 10-K - Feb. 27, 2026

data.title: COVENANT LOGISTICS GROUP, INC. SEC 10-K Report
data.description:
Covenant Logistics Group, Inc., a leading provider of transportation and logistics services, has released its 2025 10-K report, detailing the company's financial performance, business operations, strategic initiatives, and the challenges it faces in the current market environment. The report provides a comprehensive overview of the company's activities and future outlook, reflecting its commitment to operational efficiency and strategic growth.

Financial Highlights

  • Total Revenue: $1,164.5 million, reflecting an increase from $1,131.5 million in 2024, driven by growth in Managed Freight and Dedicated segments.
  • Operating Income: $2.9 million, a significant decrease from $44.8 million in 2024, impacted by increased costs and challenging market conditions.
  • Net Income: $7.2 million, or $0.27 per diluted share, compared with $35.9 million, or $1.30 per diluted share, for 2024, indicating a decline due to higher expenses and lower operating income.
  • Net Income from Continuing Operations: $4.4 million, or $0.16 per diluted share, compared to $35.3 million, or $1.28 per diluted share in 2024, reflecting reduced profitability.
  • Net Income from Discontinued Operations: $2.8 million, or $0.11 per diluted share, compared to $0.6 million, or $0.02 per diluted share in 2024, showing an increase in income from discontinued operations.

Business Highlights

  • Revenue Segments: The company operates four reportable segments: Expedited, Dedicated, Managed Freight, and Warehousing. The Expedited segment focuses on high-service freight with tight delivery windows, while the Dedicated segment provides committed truckload capacity over contracted periods. Managed Freight includes brokerage and transportation management services, and Warehousing offers day-to-day warehouse management services.
  • Operational Trends: The company has experienced significant changes in the truckload industry, including fluid supply chain patterns, rising cost structures, and increased use of technology by customers to optimize supply chains. These trends have necessitated the expansion of the company's technological capabilities to optimize asset allocation and drive operational efficiency.
  • Driver Focus: The company emphasizes the importance of drivers, employing a range of methods to improve driver careers, including safety, lifestyle, compensation, and technology enhancements. The company also faces challenges in driver recruitment and retention due to industry-wide shortages.
  • Fleet and Equipment: The company operates a modern fleet with an average tractor age of approximately 2.0 years, utilizing advanced technologies such as freight optimization software, routing software, and safety technologies to enhance operational efficiencies and driver safety.
  • Safety and Compliance: The company maintains a focus on safety, with satisfactory safety ratings from the FMCSA and ongoing implementation of safety technologies. The company also complies with various transportation and environmental regulations, which impact operations and costs.
  • Future Outlook: The company plans to continue reallocating capital to better-performing operations and expects improvements in freight fundamentals later in the year. The focus will be on high-value and high-service requirement freight, with an emphasis on operational efficiency and capturing operating leverage.
  • Regulatory Environment: The company is subject to various regulations, including those related to driver hours-of-service, emissions standards, and food safety. Changes in these regulations could impact operations and profitability.
  • Seasonality and Weather Impact: The company's operations are affected by seasonality, with decreased productivity in winter due to weather conditions and increased demand in the fourth quarter from retail customers. Weather-related disruptions can also impact operations and financial results.

Strategic Initiatives

  • Strategic Initiatives: The company is reallocating capital towards better returning operations, focusing on growing its Dedicated, Managed Freight, and Warehousing segments to become a key partner for critical transportation and logistics needs. It plans to exit unprofitable business relationships and moderately reduce its total truckload fleet while growing the most profitable components.
  • Capital Management: The company repurchased approximately 1.6 million shares of its Class A common stock for $36.2 million under a stock repurchase program authorized for up to $50 million. It also distributed $7.2 million in dividends to stockholders during 2025. The company had $338.7 million in debt and lease obligations as of December 31, 2025, with a significant portion allocated to revenue equipment installment notes.
  • Future Outlook: For 2026, the company plans to improve free cash flow and deleverage its balance sheet, with a focus on high-value and high-service requirement freight. It expects to reduce net capital expenditures significantly compared to 2025, with a baseline expectation of $40 million to $50 million. The company remains optimistic about improving freight fundamentals and aims to enhance operational efficiency and financial results later in the year.

Challenges and Risks

  • Integration Risks: The company has expanded its services through acquisitions, such as Landair, AAT, LTST, Sims, and Star, which introduces integration risks and the challenge of managing diverse operations.
  • Industry Challenges: The evolving supply chain patterns and rising costs in the truckload industry, including equipment, driver wages, and insurance premiums, pose significant challenges. The company is focused on strategic initiatives to improve operational efficiency and manage these risks.
  • Strategic Risks: The company faces strategic risks from economic, credit, business, and regulatory factors affecting the truckload industry, which are largely beyond its control. Key risks include recessionary cycles, changes in customer practices, driver shortages, regulatory compliance, and public health crises.
  • Competitive Pressures: The company is also exposed to competitive pressures, with numerous competitors potentially impacting profitability and growth opportunities. The reliance on major customers, particularly in the retail sector, poses a risk if there is a significant reduction in business.
  • Compliance Risks: Compliance risks include potential litigation, self-insurance exposure, and regulatory changes that could impact operations and profitability.
  • Operational Risks: The company also faces operational risks such as driver compensation increases, fuel price fluctuations, and dependency on third-party providers.
  • Technological Risks: Technological risks include cybersecurity threats and the need for effective information system management.
  • Management Strategies: Management is focused on improving profitability through strategic initiatives, including capital allocation, risk management, and customer experience enhancement. The company is addressing challenges such as driver retention, fuel cost management, and technological advancements to remain competitive. The impact of global conflicts and regulatory changes on supply chains and costs is being closely monitored.
  • Market Risks: The company is exposed to market risks such as fluctuations in fuel prices, interest rates, and the availability of credit. These factors could materially affect financial results, and the company is implementing strategies to mitigate these risks, including fuel surcharge programs and hedging activities.

SEC Filing: COVENANT LOGISTICS GROUP, INC. [ CVLG ] - 10-K - Feb. 27, 2026

data.title: CENTRAL PACIFIC FINANCIAL CORP SEC 10-K Report
data.description:
Central Pacific Financial Corp, the parent company of Central Pacific Bank, has released its 2025 10-K report, showcasing a year of robust financial performance and strategic growth. The company, which operates primarily in Hawaii, has demonstrated significant improvements in key financial metrics, expanded its business operations, and outlined strategic initiatives aimed at sustaining long-term growth. However, it also faces several challenges and risks inherent to its market and industry.

Financial Highlights

  • Net Income: $77.5 million, reflecting a significant increase from $53.4 million in 2024, driven by higher net interest income and other operating income.
  • Diluted EPS: $2.86, up from $1.97 in 2024, indicating improved profitability per share.
  • Return on Average Assets (ROA): 1.06%, compared to 0.72% in 2024, demonstrating enhanced asset utilization.
  • Return on Average Shareholders' Equity (ROE): 13.62%, up from 10.25% in 2024, highlighting improved return on equity.
  • Net Interest Income: $240.9 million, an increase of $29.2 million from 2024, primarily due to higher average yields on loans and investment securities.
  • Total Other Operating Income: $51.8 million, increased by $13.1 million from 2024, largely due to a reduction in losses from investment securities sales.
  • Total Other Operating Expense: $178.7 million, up by $6.1 million from 2024, mainly due to higher salaries and employee benefits.
  • Efficiency Ratio: 61.05%, improved from 68.91% in 2024, indicating better cost management relative to revenue generation.

Business Highlights

  • Branch Network: Central Pacific Bank operates 27 branches and 55 ATMs across Hawaii, with a significant presence on Oahu, Maui, Hawaii Island, and Kauai, providing full-service commercial banking.
  • Products and Services: The bank offers a comprehensive range of deposit and lending products, including commercial and industrial loans, residential mortgages, and consumer loans, alongside cash management and digital banking services.
  • Lending Activities: The bank focuses on five principal lending areas: residential mortgage, commercial and industrial, commercial mortgage, construction, and consumer lending, with a strong emphasis on real estate-related loans.
  • Heritage and Community Focus: Founded by World War II veterans, Central Pacific Bank remains committed to serving individuals and small businesses in Hawaii, emphasizing exceptional customer service and community engagement.
  • Strategic Focus: The bank aims to be a top-performing institution by focusing on small businesses and homeowners in Hawaii, strategic partnerships in Japan and Korea, and integrating wealth management services.
  • Employee Development: The company prioritizes employee growth through internal promotions, continuous learning, and career development programs, maintaining a strong focus on employee well-being and retention.
  • Market Area and Competition: Operating primarily in Hawaii, the bank is the fourth-largest depository institution in the state, competing with a wide range of financial service providers, including fintech companies.
  • Geographical Performance: The bank's operations are significantly influenced by Hawaii's economic conditions, particularly the real estate market and tourism industry, with a strong focus on local market trends.
  • Tourism Trends: Hawaii's tourism industry saw a slight decline in visitor arrivals in 2025, but visitor spending reached a record high, driven by higher per-visitor expenditures, indicating a shift towards a value-focused tourism model.
  • Interest Rates and Monetary Policy: The Federal Reserve's interest rate adjustments have influenced the bank's interest income and expense, with recent rate cuts aimed at balancing employment and inflation goals.
  • Future Outlook: The bank anticipates continued focus on strategic partnerships, diversification of its loan portfolio, and maintaining strong capital and liquidity positions to navigate economic uncertainties.

Strategic Initiatives

  • Investment Portfolio Repositioning: The company executed an investment portfolio repositioning in the fourth quarter of 2024, selling lower-yielding securities and purchasing higher-yielding ones to enhance returns.
  • Capital Management: In 2025, the company repurchased 788,261 shares of common stock at an aggregate cost of $23.3 million under its share repurchase program. It also paid cash dividends of $1.09 per share, supported by its strong capital position and consistent profitability. The company maintained a robust liquidity position with $378.7 million in cash and $2.52 billion in additional liquidity sources, representing 116% of uninsured and uncollateralized deposits.
  • Future Outlook: The company plans to continue its strategic focus on maintaining a strong capital position and liquidity, while exploring opportunities for growth in its core markets. It aims to balance its capital management strategies with sustainable growth initiatives, particularly in the Hawaii market, and to manage risks associated with economic and market conditions.

Challenges and Risks

  • Economic Risks: The geographic concentration in Hawaii exposes the company to risks from local economic downturns, particularly affecting tourism and real estate markets. Negative developments in the global and U.S. economies, such as inflation and interest rate fluctuations, could adversely impact the company's financial condition.
  • Credit Risks: A large portion of the company's loans are collateralized by real estate, making it vulnerable to declines in property values. The allowance for credit losses may not be sufficient to cover actual losses, and commercial real estate loans carry higher risks due to their size and complexity.
  • Interest Rate and Liquidity Risks: The high interest rate environment has decreased the market value of fixed-rate investment securities and loan portfolios. The company relies on the mortgage secondary market for revenue and liquidity, which could be affected by changes in government-sponsored entities' programs.
  • Operational Risks: The company is exposed to reputational risks, competition from fintech companies, and operational risks associated with third-party vendors. Technological changes, including developments in artificial intelligence, present both opportunities and challenges.
  • Regulatory Risks: Compliance with extensive federal and state regulations is costly, and changes in these regulations could adversely affect the company's operations. The company is also subject to anti-money laundering statutes and environmental laws, which could increase operational costs.
  • Climate and Environmental Risks: Climate change poses risks to the company's operations and its customers, particularly in Hawaii, where natural disasters could impact the real estate market and the company's financial condition.
  • Management Strategies: Management emphasizes the importance of maintaining a diversified funding base and managing interest rate risk. The company is focused on expanding its market position through strategic partnerships and enhancing its digital banking capabilities to remain competitive.

SEC Filing: CENTRAL PACIFIC FINANCIAL CORP [ CPF ] - 10-K - Feb. 27, 2026

data.title: Bank Stocks Suffer Another Plunge on Credit and AI Fears — WSJ
data.description:
By Ben Glickman

A chorus of concerns about AI and risky lending has bank investors spooked.

Shares in big lenders and investment banks sold off sharply Friday after new credit issues emerged and fears of broader economic implications from artificial intelligence weighed on investors.

Bank of America, Citigroup and Wells Fargo were all down more than 4%, while Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley were down over 6%. JPMorgan Chase, the biggest U.S. bank, fell about 3%.

The KBW Nasdaq Bank Index fell more than 5%, on pace for its largest one-day drop since April tariff turmoil. The country's largest lenders tend to be a proxy for investors' beliefs about the economy.

The selloff appeared to be a continuation of AI-related concerns that have roiled markets in recent weeks.

Payments company Block's decision to lay off 40% of its staff thanks to AI gains further fueled the belief that technological advancements could lead to broad job losses. That came on the heels of a report earlier this week that had investors worried about dramatic economic and job market implications of AI.

Consumer lenders, more vulnerable during economic recessions, were among the worst performers Friday including American Express, Capital One and Synchrony Financial.

Wobbling confidence in private-credit lenders has further jolted the financial sector. Several high-profile loan losses last year spurred a recent rise in redemption requests from individual investors in private-lending vehicles. On Friday, two publicly traded funds from private lenders said they were cutting their dividends, further adding to concerns.

Investors have reacted sharply to other signs more losses could be coming. They found a new example this week in the collapsed U.K. financing company Market Financial Solutions.

Market Financial Solutions offered developers and wealthy investors bridge loans on properties in London and elsewhere in the U.K., a specialty market that lets property purchasers act fast before arranging longer-term funding. Investment vehicles set up to make the loans were funded by at least half a dozen global banks and asset managers.

But in recent months, the payments stopped going into the designated accounts of the investment vehicles, according to documents in London business court. Two of the investment vehicles entered insolvency proceedings earlier this month.

Jefferies slid 10% and Barclays fell 5% on worries about the collateral on loans they made to the company.

Weakness in tech stocks and more conservative lending could also dampen what was expected to be a banner year for mergers and acquisitions and initial public offerings, said Ebrahim Poonawala, an analyst at Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

"You came in with a relatively optimistic outlook for the year, and now investors are running into risk factors that weren't necessarily at the top of their lists," he said. "Fear begets fear."
